page.title: 5.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn about properties of exponents.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Simplify expressions using different properties for exponents.
  • Simplify expressions containing exponents of zero.
  • Use the definition of a negative exponent to simplify expressions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.1.1: Understanding Exponents
  • 5.1.2: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents
    • 5.1.2: Self Check
  • 5.1.3: Using Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents
    • 5.1.3: Self Check
  • 5.1.4: Using Power Properties for Exponents
    • 5.1.4: Self Check
  • 5.1.5: Simplifying Exponents

After that, youâ€™ll practice and review.

  • 5.1.6: Practice
  • 5.1.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.1.1: Understanding Exponents
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

An exponent indicates repeated multiplication of the same quantity.

Expand each exponential expression to show repeated multiplication.


  1. \(4^3\)= ____________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4\)



  1. \(x^5\)= ____________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x\)



  1. \((-8)^6\) = ____________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8)\)



  1. \((-z)^3\) = ____________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((-z) \cdot (-z) \cdot (-z)\)

page.title: 5.1.2: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Complete the table using the Product Property for Exponents.

Product Property for Exponents

Expression

To multiply like bases, add the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(d^2 \cdot d^3\)

\(2 + 3\)

\(d^5\)

\(c^4 \cdot c^6\)

    

\(k^3 \cdot k^5\)

    

\((-v)^2 \cdot (-v)^1\)

    

\((m)^4 \cdot (m)^4\)

    

\((-p)^6 \cdot (-p)^3\)

    

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Product Property for Exponents

Expression

To multiply like bases, add the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(d^2 \cdot d^3\)

\(2 + 3\)

\(d^5\)

\(c^4 \cdot c^6\)

\(4 + 6\)

\(c^{10}\)

\(k^3 \cdot k^5\)

\(3 + 5\)

\(k^8\)

\((-v)^2 \cdot (-v)^1\)

\(2 + 1\)

\((-v)^3\)

\((m)^4 \cdot (m)^4\)

\(4 + 4\)

\(m^8\)

\((-p)^6 \cdot (-p)^8\)

\(6 + 8\)

\((-p)^{14}\)


  1. Complete the table using the Quotient Property for Exponents.

Quotient Property for Exponents

Expression

To divide like bases, subtract the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(\frac{y^5}{y^3}\)

\(5 - 3\)

\(y^2\)

\(\frac{r^4}{r}\)

    

\(\frac{q^9}{q^2}\)

    

\(\frac{(-u)^5}{(-u)^2}\)

    

\(\frac{(j)^6}{(j)^5}\)

    

\(\frac{(-z)^8}{(-z)^6}\)

    

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Quotient Property for Exponents

Expression

To divide like bases, subtract the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(\frac{y^5}{y^3}\)

\(5 - 3\)

\(y^2\)

\(\frac{r^4}{r}\)

\(4 - 1\)

\(r^3\)

\(\frac{q^9}{q^2}\)

\(9 - 2\)

\(q^7\)

\(\frac{(-u)^5}{(-u)^2}\)

\(5 - 2\)

\((-u)^3\)

\(\frac{(j)^6}{(j)^5}\)

\(6 - 5\)

\(j^1\)

\(\frac{(-z)^8}{(-z)^6}\)

\(8 - 6\)

\((-z)^2 = z^2\)

page.title: 5.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following equations is correct?

answer.response: Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.

Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents rather than multiplying. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents rather than dividing. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents rather than dividing. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

When we combine like terms by adding and subtracting, we need to have the same base with the same exponent. But when you multiply and divide, the exponents may be different, and sometimes the bases may be different, too.

First, we will look at an example that leads to the Product Property.

What does \(x^2 \cdot x^3\) mean?


Notice that 5 is the sum of the exponents, 2 and 3. We see \(x^2 \cdot x^3\) is \(x^{2+3}\) or \(x^5\).

The base stayed the same, and we added the exponents. This leads to the Product Property for Exponents.


PRODUCT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(a^m \cdot a^n=a^{m+n}\)

To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.


Now we will look at an exponent property for division. As before, weâ€™ll try to discover a property by looking at some examples.

  1. Consider \(\frac{x^5}{x^2}\)

Step 1
What does it mean? \(\frac{x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x}{x \cdot x}\)

Step 2
Use the Equivalent Fractions Property.
x   Â·   x   Â·   x   Â·   x   Â·   x x   Â·   x

Step 3
Simplify.
\(x^3\)

  1. Consider \(\frac{x^2}{x^3}\)

Step 1
What does it mean?
\(\frac{x \cdot x}{x \cdot x \cdot x}\)

Step 2
Use the Equivalent Fractions Property.
x   Â·   x   Â·   1 x   Â·   x   Â·   x

Step 3
Simplify.
\(\frac1x\)

Notice that in each case, the bases were the same and we subtracted exponents. We see \(\frac{x^5}{x^2}\) is \(x^{5-2}\) or \(x^3\). We see \(\frac{x^2}{x^3}\) is \(\frac1x\). When the larger exponent was in the numerator, we were left with factors in the numerator. When the larger exponent was in the denominator, we were left with factors in the denominatorâ€”notice the numerator of 1. When all the factors in the numerator have been removed, remember this is really dividing the factors to one, so we need a 1 in the numerator. x x   = 1 . This leads to the Quotient Property for Exponents.


QUOTIENT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number, \(a\neq0\), and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n}\), \(m>n\) and \(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=\frac1{a^{n-m}}\), \(n>m\)


Try It: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

Simplify each expression.

  1. \( h^4 \cdot h^7\)
  2. \((-s)^2 \cdot (-s)^2\)
  3. \(\frac {b^7}{b^5}\)
  4. \({(-y)^6}{(-y)^3}\)
  5. \(\frac{x^3}{x^5}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. \(h^4 \cdot h^7= h^{11}\)
  2. \( (-s)^2(-s)^2=(-s)^4 \)
  3. \(\frac{b^7}{b^5} = b^2\)
  4. \(\frac{(-y)^6}{(-y)^3} = (-y)^3\)
  5. \(\frac{ x^3}{x^5}=\frac{1}{x^2}\)

Video: Understanding Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

Watch the following video to learn more about applying the Product and Quotient Properties of Exponents.

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.1.3: Using Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents
page.contents:
Activity


  1. Complete the table using the Zero Exponent Property.

Zero Exponent Property

Expression

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.

Simplified Result

\(d^0\)

  

\(7^0\)

  

\((-8)^0\)

  

\((-v)^0\)

  

\(r^0 \cdot r^0\)

  

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

The Zero Exponent Property is any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1, the simplified result to each expression is 1!

Zero Exponent Property

Expression

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.

Simplified Result

\(d^0\)

\(1\)

\(7^0\)

\(1\)

\((-8)^0\)

\(1\)

\((-v)^0\)

\(1\)

\(r^0 \cdot r^0\)

\(1\)



  1. Complete the table using the definition of a negative exponent.

Definition of a Negative Exponent

Expression

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Simplified Result

\(g^{-4}\)

  

\(2^{-3}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{c^{-2}}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{(-h)^{-6}}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{4^{-3}}\)

  

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Definition of a Negative Exponent

Expression

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Simplified Result

\(g^{-4}\)

\(\frac{1}{g^4}\)

\(2^{-3}\)

\(\frac{1}{2^3}\) or \(\frac18\)

\(\frac{1}{c^{-2}}\)

\(c^2\)

\(\frac{1}{(-h)^{-6}}\)

\((-h)^6\)

\(\frac{1}{4^{-3}}\)

\(4^3\) or \(64\)

page.title: 5.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following equations is correct?

answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: Any non-zero base raised to the power of zero equals 1. The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).
Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The â€“6 is an exponent, not a factor. Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\), so \(w^{-6}=\frac{1}{w^6}\). The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).

Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This is the result of finding the opposite of \(7^3\). Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\), so \(7^{-3}=\frac{1}{7^3}\). The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).
Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using the Zero Exponent Property

A special case of the Quotient Property is when the exponents of the numerator and denominator are equal, such as an expression like \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\). We know \(\frac{x}{x}=1\) for any \(x\) (\(x\neq0\)) since any number divided by itself is 1. The Quotient Property for Exponents shows us how to simplify \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\) when \(m>n\) and when \(n<m\) by subtracting exponents. What if \(m=n\)? We will simplify \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\) in two ways to lead us to the definition of the Zero Exponent Property. In general, for \(a\neq0\):


ZERO EXPONENT PROPERTY

If \(a\) is a non-zero number, then \(a^0=1\).

If \(a\) is a non-zero number, then \(a\) to the power of zero equals 1.

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.


Using the Definition of a Negative Exponent

We saw that the Quotient Property for Exponents has two forms depending on whether the exponent is larger in the numerator or the denominator. What if we just subtract exponents regardless of which is larger?

Letâ€™s consider \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\). We subtract the exponent in the denominator from the exponent in the numerator. We see \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\) is \(x^{2-5}\) or \(x^{-3}\).

We can also simplify \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\) by dividing out common factors:

\(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\)

x   Â·   x x Â· x Â· x Â· x Â· x

\(\frac{1}{x^3}\)

This implies that \(x^{-3}=\frac{1}{x^3}\), and it leads us to the definition of a negative exponent. If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Letâ€™s now look at what happens to a fraction whose numerator is one and whose denominator is an integer raised to a negative exponent.

\(\frac{1}{a^{âˆ’n}}\)

Step 1
Use the definition of a negative exponent, \(a^{âˆ’n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).
\(\frac{1}{\frac{1}{a^n}}\)

Step 2
Simplify the complex fraction.
\(1 \cdot \frac{a^n}{1}\)
\(\frac{x \cdot x}{x \cdot x \cdot x}\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(a^n\)



This implies \(\frac{1}{a^{-n}}=a^n\) and is another form of the definition of Properties of Negative Exponents.


PROPERTIES OF NEGATIVE EXPONENTS

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{âˆ’n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\) or \(\frac{1}{a^{âˆ’n}}=a^n\).


The negative exponent tells us we can rewrite the expression by taking the reciprocal of the base and then changing the sign of the exponent.

Any expression that has negative exponents is not considered to be in simplest form. We will use the definition of a negative exponent and other properties for exponents to write the expression with only positive exponents.

For example, if after simplifying an expression we end up with the expression \(x^{-3}\), we will take one more step and write \(\frac{1}{x^3}\). The answer is considered to be in simplest form when it has only positive exponents.

Try It: Using the Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents

Simplify each expression.

  1. \( h^0\)
  2. \(7^0\)
  3. \( (-g)^0\)
  4. \(a^{-4}\)
  5. \(9^{-3}\)
  6. \(\frac{1}{n^{-5}}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. 1
  2. 1
  3. 1
  4. \(\frac{1}{a^4}\)
  5. \(\frac{1}{9^3}=\frac{1}{729}\)
  6. \(n^5\)

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.1.4: Using Power Properties for Exponents
page.contents:
Activity

Work with a partner to complete the activity. Discuss any differences in the simplified results you find. Make sure you both understand each step you take to simplify.

  1. Complete the table using the Quotient to a Negative Power Property for exponents.

Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)

  

\((-\frac{y}{z})^{-7}\)

  

\((\frac{g}{h})^{-6}\)

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)

\((\frac{7}{3})^5 = (\frac{7^5}{3^5}) = \frac{16,807}{243}\)

\((-\frac{y}{z})^{-7}\)

\((-\frac{z}{y})^7 = -\frac{z^7}{y^7}\)

\((\frac{g}{h})^{-6}\)

\((\frac{h}{g})^6 =\frac{ h^6}{g^6}\)
  1. Complete the table using the Power Property for Exponents.

Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

Simplified Result

\((4^2)^5\)

  

\((n^3)^7\)

  

\((2^3)^2(d^4)^3\)

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

Simplified Result

\((4^2)^5\)

\(4^{10} = 1,048,576\)

\((n^3)^7\)

\(n^{21}\)

\((2^3)^2(d^4)^3\)

\((2^6)(d^{12}) = 64d^{12}\)
  1. Complete the table using the Product to a Power Property for exponents.

Product to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Simplified Result

\((-2tv)^7\)

  

\((4pr^2)^5\)

  

\((3h^3)^{-2}\)

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Product to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Simplified Result

\((-2tv)^7\)

\((-2)^7t^7v^7 = -128t^7v^7\)

\((4pr^2)^5\)

\(4^5p^5r^{10} = 1,024p^5r^{10}\)

\((3h^3)^{-2}\)

\((\frac{1}{3h^3})^2 = \frac{1}{3^2h^6} = \frac{1}{9h^6}\)
  1. Complete the table using the Quotient to a Power Property for exponents.

Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{j}{9})^3\)

  

\((\frac{5}{m})^2\)

  

\((\frac{y}{w})^{-5}\)

  

\((\frac{3ab^3}{c^2})^4\)

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{j}{9})^3\)

\(\frac{j^3}{9^3} = \frac{j^3}{729}\)

\((\frac{5}{m})^2\)

\((\frac{5}{m})^2=\frac{5^2}{m^2}=\frac{m^2}{25}\)

\((\frac{y}{w})^{-5}\)

\((\frac{w}{y})^5 = \frac{w^5}{y^5}\)

\((\frac{3ab^3}{c^2})^4\)

\(\frac{3^4a^4b^{12}}{c^8} =\frac {81a^4b^{12}}{c^8}\)

Choose one example above and explain each step to your partner. Listen as your partner does the same for you.

answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This is the simplified form of the expression without raising it to the power of 3. Remember to raise each factor in parentheses to the power of 3. Did you find \(3^9\)? Did you use the Power Property on \(x\) and \(q\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\).
Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: We use the Power Property on each part. \(3^9 = 19,683\). The negative exponent on \(x\) moves it to the denominator where it becomes positive.
Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This is the value if you add the exponents when you raise \(3^3\) to the power of 3. Did you find \(3^9\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\).
Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: Did you address the negative exponent on \(x\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.1.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Quotient to a Negative Power Property

Suppose now we have a fraction raised to a negative exponent. Letâ€™s use our definition of negative exponents to lead us to a new property.


\((\frac34)^{âˆ’2}\)

Step 1
Use the definition of a negative exponent, \(a^{âˆ’n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).
\(\frac{1}{(\frac{3}{4})^2}\)

Step 2
Simplify the denominator.
\(\frac1{\frac9{16}}\)

Step 3
Simplify the complex fraction.
\(\frac{16}{9}\)
But we know that \(\frac{16}{9}\) is \((\frac{4}{3})^2\).

Step 4
This tells us that
\((\frac{3}{4})^{âˆ’2}=(\frac{4}{3})^2\)


To get from the original fraction raised to a negative exponent to the final result, we took the reciprocal of the baseâ€”the fractionâ€”and changed the sign of the exponent.

This leads us to the Quotient to a Negative Power Property.


QUOTIENT TO A NEGATIVE POWER PROPERTY

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{b})^n\)


Now that we have negative exponents, we can use the Product Property we learned in Activity 5.1.2 with expressions that have negative exponents, too.

Power Property for Exponents

Now letâ€™s look at an exponential expression that contains a power raised to a power. See if you can discover a general property.

What does this mean?

Notice the 6 is the product of the exponents, 2 and 3. We see that \((x^2)^3\) is \(x^{2 \cdot 3}\) or \(x^6\).

We multiplied the exponents. This leads to the Power Property for Exponents.


POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

To raise a power to a power, multiply the exponents.


Product to a Power Property for Exponents

We will now look at an expression containing a product that is raised to a power. Can you find this pattern?


\((2x)^3\)

Step 1
What does this mean?
\(2x \cdot 2x \cdot 2x \)

Step 2
We group the like factors together.
\(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x\)

Step 3
How many factors of 2 and of \(x\)?
\(2^3 \cdot x^3\)


Notice that each factor was raised to the power and \((2x)^3\) is \(2^3 \cdot x^3\).

The exponent applies to each of the factors. This leads to the Product to a Power Property for Exponents.


PRODUCT TO A POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

To raise a product to a power, raise each factor to that power.


Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Now we will look at an example that will lead us to the Quotient to a Power Property.


\((\frac{x}{y})^3\)

Step 1
This means
\(\frac{x}{y} \cdot \frac{x}{y} \cdot \frac{x}{y}\)

Step 2
Multiply the fractions.
\(\frac{x \cdot x \cdot x}{y \cdot y \cdot y}\)

Step 3
Write with exponents.
\(\frac{x^3}{y^3}\)


Notice that the exponent applies to both the numerator and the denominator.

We see that \((\frac{x}{y})^3\) is \(\frac{x^3}{y^3}\).

This leads to the Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents.


QUOTIENT TO A POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

To raise a fraction to a power, raise the numerator and denominator to that power.


Try It: Using Power Properties for Exponents

Simplify each expression using the property identified.

Use the Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \( (\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)
  2. \(( -\frac{r}{s})^{-2}\)

Use the Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((x^3)^5\)
  2. \((2^2)^3\)
  3. \((h^4)^5(h^2)^2\)

Use the Product to a Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((-2cd)^6\)
  2. \( (4z)^{-3}\)

Use the Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((\frac{ 2xy^2}{z})^3\)
  1. \((\frac{4p^{-3}}{q^2})^2 \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. \( (\frac{3}{7})^{-5} = (\frac{7}{3})^5= \frac{7^5}{3^5} = \frac{16,807}{243}\)
  1. \((-\frac{r}{s})^{-2} = (-\frac{s}{r})^2= \frac{s^2}{r^2}\)
  1. \((x^3)^5 = x^{15}\)
  1. \( (2^2)^3 = 2^6 = 64\)
  1. \( (h^4)^5(h^2)^2 = (h^{20})(h^4) = h^{24}\)
  1. \((-2cd)^6 = (-2)^6c^6d^6 = 64c^6d^6\)
  1. \((4z)^{-3} = \frac{1}{(4z)^3} = \frac{1}{4^3z^3} =\frac{1}{64z^3}\)
  1. \((\frac{2xy^2}{z})^3\)

    2. Step 1
    Use Quotient to a Power Property, \((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\).
    \(\frac{(2xy^2)^3}{z^3}\)

    Step 2
    Use the Product to a Power Property, \((ab)^m=a^mb^m\).
    \(\frac{8x^3y^6}{z^3}\)

  1. \((\frac{4p^{âˆ’3}}{q^2})^2\)

    2. Step 1
    Use Quotient to a Power Property, \((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\).
    \(\frac{(4p^{âˆ’3})^2}{(q^2)^2}\)

    Step 2
    Use the Product to a Power Property,\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\).
    \(\frac{4^2(p^{âˆ’3})^2}{(q^2)^2}\)

    Step 3
    Simplify using the Power Property,\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\).
    \(\frac{16p^{âˆ’6}}{q^4}\)

    Step 4
    Use the definition of negative exponent.
    \(\frac{16}{q^4} \cdot \frac{1}{p^6}\)

    Step 5
    Simplify.
    \(\frac{16}{p^6q^4}\)

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.1.5: Simplifying Exponents
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Complete the table using all of the exponent properties you learned in the lesson.

Exponent Property Review

Expression

Simplified Result

\(j^5 \cdot j^3\)

\(\frac{h^7}{h^3}\)

\((-ab)^0\)

\(\frac{1}{s^{-4}}\)

\((\frac{m}{n})^{-4}\)

\((p^5)^2\)

\((3s^3t^2)^3\)

\((\frac{b}{d})^{-2}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:


Exponent Property Review

Expression

Simplified Result

\(j^5 \cdot j^3\)

\(j^8\)

\(\frac{h^7}{h^3}\)

\(h^4\)

\((-ab)^0\)

\(1\)

\(\frac{1}{s^{-4}}\)

\(s^4\)

\((\frac{m}{n})^{-4}\)

\(\frac{n^4}{m^4}\)

\((p^5)^2\)

\(p^{10}\)

\((3s^3t^2)^3\)

\(3^3s^9t^6 = 27s^9t^6\)

\((\frac{b}{d})^{-2}\)

\(\frac{d^2}{b^2}\)

Take some time to review each of the exponential properties you learned in the lesson. Look at each property and be sure you know when to use it.


SUMMARY OF EXPONENT PROPERTIES

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

Property

Description

Product Property

\(a^m \cdot a^n={a^{m+n}}\)

Power Property

\((a^m)^n=a^{mÂ·n}\)

Product to a Power

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Quotient Property

\(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{mâˆ’n}\), \(a\neq0\)

Zero Exponent Property

\(a^0=1\), \(a\neq0\)

Quotient to a Power Property

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\), \(b\neq0\)

Properties of Negative Exponents

\(a^{âˆ’n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\) and \(\frac{1}{a^{âˆ’n}}=a^n\)

Quotient to a Negative Exponent

\((\frac{a}{b})^{âˆ’n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n \)

page.title: 5.1.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Simplify each expression using the appropriate property from the lesson.

  1. \(f^2 \cdot f^6\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f^8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(\frac{(-y)^6}{(-y)^3}\)

Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((-y)^3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((-4)^0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(2^{-3}\)

Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac18\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(\frac{1}{(-t)^{-5}}\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((-t)^5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((-\frac{m}{n})^{-3}\)

Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(-\frac{n^3}{m^3}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((d^3)^5\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \( d^{15}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(( 5x^{-2})^3\)

Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac{125}{x^6}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((\frac{7b^3c}{d^2})^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(\frac{49b^6c^2}{d^4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((\frac{3^z{-2}}{w^2})^{-2}\)

Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac{z^4w^4}{9}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.1.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Simplify expressions using different properties for exponents.
  • Simplify expressions containing exponents of zero.
  • Use the definition of a negative exponent to simplify expressions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.1.1: Understanding Exponents
    • In this activity, you reviewed the concept of exponents. You converted exponential expressions into repeated multiplication expressions.
  • 5.1.2: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents
    • In this activity, you learned how to use the Product Property for Exponents to rewrite multiplication problems involving exponential terms with the same base. To simplify, the exponential terms are added and the same base is kept. You also learned how to use the Quotient Property for Exponents to rewrite division problems involving exponential terms with the same base. To simplify those, the exponential terms are subtracted and the same base is kept.
  • 5.1.2: Self Check
  • 5.1.3: Using Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents
    • In this activity, you used the Zero Exponent Property to simplify any non-zero number raised to the zero power. The solution is always 1. You also learned how to use the definition of a negative exponent to simplify exponential expressions. To simplify an expression with a negative exponent, the reciprocal of the base is used and the sign of the exponent is flipped.
  • 5.1.3: Self Check
  • 5.1.4: Using Power Properties for Exponents
    • In this activity, you learned various power properties for exponents. The Quotient to a Negative Power Property is used to simplify values being divided while all raised to a negative exponent. You learned that the Power Property for Exponents is used when an exponential expression is raised to another power. The Product to a Power Property for Exponents states that when you raise products to a power, all factors being multiplied are raised to that power. Finally, you learned the Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents. This is used to simplify a division expression that is raised to a power.
  • 5.1.4: Self Check
  • 5.1.5: Simplifying Exponents
    • In this activity, you simplified expressions using all the properties you practiced in the lesson. You also reviewed each of the properties you learned.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.1.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If youâ€™ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
